Description: Body sherd belonging to a pottery flask (gourd) or a keg (barrel) produced in the Western Oasis of Egypt (although has also been interpreted as a fragment of an amphora shoulder); characteristic clay with a light yellowish salmon section and moderate, mixed but not well-sorted mineral inclusions (quartz, white and grey inclusions); external surface rather rough, dark brown in colour, with a probably painted inscription in lighter reddish brown.
Production place: Made in: Western Desert, Fabric typical of Western Egyptian Oasis
Curator's comments: M. Pesenti takes the jar as Palestinian.

However, according to the fabric, it is in Oasis ware. The fragment could belong to either a gourd or a keg produced in the Western Oasis. A second production from the Oasis was discovered in Naukratis (BM 1886,1005.15). On kegs and gourds produced in the Western Oasis of Egypt see: Hope, C.A. Eccleston, M. A. Kaper, O. E. Marchand, S. and Darnell, D. 2000, ‘Kegs and Flasks from Dakhleh Oasis’, Cahiers de la Céramique Egyptienne 6, 189-234. Rougeulle, A and Marchand, S. 2011, ‘Des siga sur la côte du Hadramawt (Yémen): témoins d’une attaque navale?’, Cahiers de la Céramique Egyptienne 9, 437-460.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (IB.098)
